replicas.replicaText: So, how're you holding up, Ken?
Oh, just living the dream, Paul. I can't believe I'm the President of the United States.
Yeah, it's pretty crazy.
But, you know, now that you're in the big chair, we've got some work to do.

subreplicasOption2.subReplicaText: I'm afraid it won't work out, buddy.

replicas.replicaText: We need to get started on that big construction project we talked about during the campaign.

subreplicasOption2.subReplicaText: Are you kidding? This is our main project.

replicas.replicaText: The technology boom has made it uneconomical for most private factories to pay workers for work that can be done by a machine.
Hundreds of thousands of people lost their jobs.
The unemployment rate in the country is now at a record high since the Great Depression.
Even the covid year of 2020 was not so severe.
I hope that our plan for the Great Construction will pay off.
The factories we are planning to build should not only provide hundreds of thousands of Americans with jobs, but also bring in revenue to the state budget.
You bet. It's going to be huge, Ken. People are going to see real change.
That's the spirit, Mr. President. Let's make America great again.
Greetings, Mr. President. This office suits you very well.
You'll get used to it.
Yeah, I'm going to have to get used to a lot of things.
Not my coffee. Everyone likes it.
And yes, the head of the US Army, Macon Farrell, is here to see you.
hm...
Good afternoon, Commander. Please have a seat.
Thank you, Mr. President. Congratulations on your inauguration.
As Commander-in-Chief of the United States Army, I look forward to working with you, Mr. President.
I appreciate that, Macon. Can you give me an update on the state of the army?
Yes, Mr. President. The army is in good shape. We're focusing on modernization and improving our readiness.

subreplicasOption1.subReplicaText: Our alliances are strong, Mr. President. We're working with our partners to maintain peace and stability around the world.
The only one who worries me is China.

subreplicasOption2.subReplicaText: China is currently the main concern, Mr. President.

replicas.replicaText: Their military is expanding rapidly, and they pose a significant challenge to US interests.
What steps are we taking to address this threat?
We're working to increase our presence in the Indo-Pacific region, Mr. President.
We're also enhancing our partnerships with allies and improving our capabilities.
I see. We need to be prepared for any scenario.
Absolutely, Mr. President. The United States Army is ready to protect our nation and our interests.
Thank you, Mr. President. It's an honor to serve our country.
Mr. President. Ministers from other countries will call you throughout the day with congratulations. One of them on the phone right now.
It's just a formality. But you should answer them.
You don't even have to listen to them. I will tell you what they will sing.
Congratulations, Mr. President. we have believed in your victory all along and we look forward to working closely together. Blah, blah, blah.
Yeah. That's how I believed that the communists in Russia believed in our victory.
They are the ones on your phone right now.
Yes, of course. Thank you.
Don't pick up the phone, Ken?
These are the rules of politeness and political communication.
I think I can handle it, guys. Now let me pick up the phone.
Mr. President, the Minister of Justice is here to see you.
Thank you, Roberta. Send him in.
Congratulations, Mr. President. Your victory is a great moment for our country.
Thank you, Minister. It's good to have you here. So, what's the state of justice in our country?
Well, Mr. President, it's a mixed bag. On one hand, we're making progress in reducing crime rates and improving the efficiency of our legal system.
On the other hand, we're facing challenges like cybercrime and issues with law enforcement.
I have a few ideas, Mr. President. We need to invest in training and technology for our law enforcement agencies, as well as increase funding for crime prevention programs.
We also need to modernize our legal system and make it more accessible to everyone.
Is there anything else you'd like to add?
Just that I'm excited to work with you, Mr. President. Together, I'm confident we can make real progress in improving justice in our country.
Mr. President? There are some documents here that you need to sign. I'll leave them on your desk.
Hey Ken, congratulations on signing that education bill. That's a big win for you.
Thanks, Paul. I'm glad we could get it done.
Yeah, but you know what's even bigger than education? Monuments.
James Taylor from the Ministry of Construction and Urban Development is on the phone. He's got an idea for a monument that will put the Statue of Liberty to shame.
Mr. President, congratulations on your election victory.
Thank you, Russ. It's good to see you. What brings you here?
I wanted to give you an update on the budget situation. Unfortunately, your predecessors have left you with a bit of a mess.
The budget is in a deficit, and we're looking at some tough choices in the near future. I know you have a lot of plans to help improve the country, but we need to be careful with spending.
I understand. What are the main problems in our economy right now?
Well, as you know, unemployment is quite high, and the tax system is uneven. We need to find ways to encourage more job growth and ensure that everyone is paying their fair share.
I see. Do you have any proposals for how we can address these issues?
I've put together a plan to increase job growth by investing in infrastructure and renewable energy. We can also reform the tax system to make it more equitable for everyone.
We can start by cutting wasteful spending and reducing subsidies for big corporations. We can also increase taxes on the wealthiest Americans.
I'm sure there will be some pushback on that last point.
Yes, there will be. But it's time for the wealthy to start paying their fair share. It's time for everyone to have a chance at success, not just the privileged few.

subreplicasOption2.subReplicaText: I have a few people in mind.

replicas.replicaText: I'll start putting together a list of candidates.
Great. Let's make it happen.
What do you think of Russ? His white hair... he looks like an evil genius with it.
Minister of Energy Kaden Thompson is here.
There he is. Tell him we're waiting for him.
Something important, you think?
Probably something to do with the situation in the east.
Thank you, Mr. President. It's an honor to be here.
Hey, Kaden. How are you doing?
Wonderful, thanks.
What can I do for you today?
Well, sir, I wanted to discuss the state of the energy industry with you.
As you know, the energy supply in the United States is sufficient at the moment, but due to the war in Iran, oil prices have risen dramatically, and so have energy prices.
Paul: Told you...
We need to find a way to increase energy revenues.
I think we need to focus on developing renewable energy sources, like wind and solar power.
This will not only help reduce our reliance on oil but also provide more jobs in the clean energy sector.
We could also offer tax incentives to businesses that invest in clean energy technology.
That's a good start.
Yes, but we need to think bigger. How about we look into offshore wind farms? The potential for wind power is huge...
… and it would create a lot of jobs in the construction and maintenance of the farms.
This could work. We have a lot of coastline in the United States, and we could definitely take advantage of that.
But we need to make sure we have the necessary infrastructure in place to support it.
Absolutely. We can also look into expanding our nuclear energy program.
Nuclear power has its risks, but it's also a reliable source of energy that doesn't depend on oil.
And we have the technology to make it safer than ever before.
I agree. We already have a few nuclear power plants in operation, and we could definitely expand that program.
Good. I’ll start working with my team on a plan to increase our energy revenues and reduce our dependence on oil.
It's a tough challenge, but we have faith in you, Kaden.
Oh, thanks. I won't let you down.
Thank you for your time, Mr. President.
You have two more meetings scheduled for today, sir. NASA Chairman Tilly Mason is waiting for you.
I'm expecting her as well.
Good afternoon, Mr. President.
Hello, Tilly. I've heard all about you.
You have? What do they say about me?
A young, beautiful girl with a major position at NASA. It was all over the news.
I'm glad to hear that. Especially coming from you.
So, Tilly... what's the latest news from our Mars rover?
Mr. President, the latest data indicates a large amount of useful minerals and iron on the planet.
Yes, sir. The most powerful countries are already setting their sights on these resources.

subreplicasOption1.subReplicaText: They always want to be the first to get their hands on anything that could give them an edge.

replicas.replicaText: It's a race to the finish, Mr. President. And the competition is fierce.
I know. But we have to be careful not to make any rash decisions. We need to assess the situation and figure out the best way to proceed.
I agree, sir. It's important that we approach this with caution and make sure we're making the right choices for our country.
Absolutely, Tilly. We can't let the lure of resources cloud our judgment. We have to stay focused on what's best for America.
Good evening, Mr. President. I hope you're doing well.
I'm fine, Seth. What brings you here today?
I wanted to talk to you about the current state of affairs, Mr. President. As you know, the country is going through a lot of turmoil right now.
We're dealing with rising crime rates, rising political tensions, and a general sense of unease among the population.
We're doing everything we can to keep the situation under control, Mr. President.
Our agents are working around the clock to investigate and prevent crime, and we are working with other agencies to address the root causes of the problem.
That's great to hear. What can we do to support your efforts?
We could use more resources and funding to expand our operations and become more efficient. But I think we can do that next time. You've had a busy day. I just wanted to say congratulations.
It's been a tough day indeed. Thank you for the congratulations.

choices.option1: Absolutely. I'm ready to hit the ground running. What's first on our list?
choices.option2: And I wanted to rest a little more.
Can you remind me? My head is swimming with these elections.

choices.option1: And the crisis in 2023 made itself felt. Many factories closed due to bankruptcy.
choices.option2: So what?

choices.option1: Well, let's get to work then.
choices.option2: We've got a lot of promises to keep.

choices.option1: And this is all the work of the president of the United States?
choices.option2: Got it. Easy-peasy.

choices.option1: Really? And I was thinking of doing a full renovation.
choices.option2: The spirit of capitalism is preserved.
I'll take a double shot.
And I thought it would be a beautiful day...
It's an honor to be the President of the United States.

choices.option1: That's good to hear. What about our allies?
choices.option2: What about potential threats to our national security?

choices.option1: I have faith in your leadership, Macon.
choices.option2: Thank you for your service.

choices.option1: What can we do to improve things?
choices.option2: How do you propose we address these issues?

choices.option1: Those are good suggestions, Minister. I'll definitely take them into consideration.
choices.option2: I'll make sure to include them in our discussions.

choices.option1: Thank you, Minister. I'm looking forward to working with you too.
choices.option2: Minister, your dedication is commendable. I'm eager to collaborate with you as well.
I know, Roberta.
What are you talking about?
I had no doubt about it.
But how do we fund these initiatives?

choices.option1: I agree. We're going to need a strong team to make this happen.
choices.option2: Do you have anyone in mind for the job?
Kinda creepy, huh?
Please take a seat.
What kind of plan do you have in mind?
Thank you for coming in today, Kaden.
That's interesting.
I think we won't stand aside.

choices.option1: I'm aware of the situation, Seth.
choices.option2: What's your assessment of the situation?

decisions.characterName: Edgar Gildon, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
decisions.text:
President Rothwell, congratulations once again on your remarkable victory. I am confident that, under your leadership, the bond between our two great nations will grow even stronger. As you know, the United Kingdom and the United States have long shared a special relationship, built on trust, mutual respect, and shared values.
To further deepen this bond, I propose a significant trade agreement that would prioritize UK exports to the US, particularly in key sectors like technology, pharmaceuticals, and renewable energy. This agreement could bring substantial economic benefits to both our nations and send a clear message to the world about our unwavering partnership.
However, this deal would require your administration to relax certain tariffs on British goods, which may face opposition from some of your domestic industries. I understand it’s a challenging decision, but I believe the benefits of reinforcing our alliance far outweigh the drawbacks. Together, we can showcase what true global leadership looks like. What do you say, Mr. President?

decisions.characterName: James Taylor, Minister of Housing and Urban Development
decisions.text:
Mr. President, in celebration of your historic inauguration, I propose the announcement of a new monumental project that will stand as a symbol of your leadership. You have three options for this iconic monument:
 Eagle's Embrace: A grand sculpture of an eagle, wings outstretched, cradling the American flag, symbolizing freedom, strength, and the nation's resilience.
 The Unity Pillars: A series of towering columns, each representing a core American value such as liberty, justice, and equality, emphasizing the unity of our nation.
 Harmony Arch: An elegant, sweeping arch that reflects the diversity and inclusivity of the United States, celebrating the harmonious coexistence of different cultures and backgrounds.

decisions.characterName: Kaiden Altman, Prime Minister of Canada
decisions.text: President Rothwell, I extend my sincere congratulations on your election as the President of the United States. This is a momentous occasion, and I believe that our two nations can continue to strengthen our close friendship and cooperation. Canada looks forward to working with you to address shared challenges and to build a better future for our citizens. Please accept my best wishes for a successful term.

decisions.characterName: Nobu Kawasaki, Prime Minister of Japan
decisions.text: President Rothwell, on behalf of the people of Japan, I extend my heartfelt congratulations on your recent election as the President of the United States. Your leadership holds great significance not only for your nation but also for the international community. Japan looks forward to strengthening our bilateral relations and fostering cooperation on shared global challenges. Please accept my warmest wishes for a successful and prosperous term.

President Rothwell, please accept my sincere congratulations on your election as the President of the United States. This marks a new chapter in our bilateral relations, and I am confident that under your leadership, our countries will continue to build strong ties and address global challenges together. Poland looks forward to deepening our cooperation and friendship. I wish you a successful and impactful tenure.

laws.mainText: Increase Funding for Public Schools and Universities
laws.detailedText: This proposal calls for significantly increasing funding to improve educational quality and access. Enhanced resources will boost academic programs, infrastructure, and educator support, fostering a more knowledgeable generation.

laws.mainText: Establishing Stricter Emission Rules for Vehicles.
laws.detailedText: In response to environmental concerns, this proposal suggests implementing stricter vehicle emission standards. These measures aim to reduce air pollution, address climate change, and protect public health.
laws.preparedBy:
Rosa Martin,
head of the EP departament

laws.mainText: Stimulating Innovation and Entrepreneurship in the Economy.
laws.detailedText: To boost economic growth, this proposal advocates for policies supporting entrepreneurship, including tax incentives and incubation centers. Encouraging startups will create jobs, enhance competitiveness, and drive national progress.

laws.mainText: Promoting Access to Justice for All.
laws.detailedText: This proposal seeks to expand legal aid, establish community justice centers, and enhance pro bono services. These measures aim to ensure fair access to justice and protect citizens' rights.

news.headerText: What is known about the newly elected President Ken Rothwell?
news.detailedText: President-elect Ken Rothwell, with nearly two decades of experience in the IT and technology sectors, brings expertise in economic management and scientific knowledge to politics.

news.headerText: President Ken Rothwell Assumes Office, Sworn in to Fulfill Presidential Duties
news.detailedText: In a historic ceremony, President Ken Rothwell has taken the oath of office, beginning his role as the U.S. leader. He pledges to uphold national values, address challenges, and work for the welfare of the American people as a new era of leadership unfolds.

news.headerText: President Ken Rothwell Vows Economic Recovery Amid Record Unemployment
news.detailedText: With the economy struggling and unemployment at record highs, President Ken Rothwell promises to end the economic crisis during his presidency. His agenda focuses on restoring stability, creating jobs, and leading the nation to financial recovery.

characterSubtitles: President: Good morning, everyone. I hope you're all ready for a productive meeting. Let's start with the latest updates from the CIA, Patrick.

Patrick Miller (CIA Director): Good morning, Mr. President. As I mentioned in our previous meeting, there are no critical conflicts at the moment, and our intelligence teams are actively monitoring global events. However, I must bring a matter to your attention. We recently discovered several letters containing threats against your life.
President: That's deeply concerning. Have we been able to determine the source or credibility of these threats?

Patrick Miller: We have launched a thorough investigation, Mr. President. Our forensic experts are examining the letters for any traces of the sender's identity. Additionally, our analysts are assessing the credibility of the threats based on available intelligence.
President: I appreciate your swift response, Patrick. Please ensure that every necessary measure is taken to guarantee my safety and the security of our administration.

Patrick Miller: Absolutely, Mr. President. We have already enhanced your security detail and implemented additional protective measures. Our agents are coordinating closely with the Secret Service to mitigate any potential risks

Olivia: Mr. President, I want to assure you that we are actively managing this situation from a public relations standpoint. We are working to maintain calm and reassure the public of their safety while being transparent about the ongoing investigation.
President: Thank you, Olivia. It's crucial to strike the right balance between transparency and not causing unnecessary alarm. Please keep me updated on the progress of our communication efforts.
Olivia: Of course, Mr. President. We are closely monitoring media coverage and engaging with key stakeholders to ensure accurate information is disseminated while minimizing speculation.
President: Excellent. Let's remain vigilant and address these threats with utmost seriousness.
